profiledesc.creation: Finding Aid encoded by Library of Congress Music Division, 2008

change.item: Editorial revisions made to this finding aid by Nancy Seeger in March 2010.

did.head: Collection Summary

physdesc.label: Extent
physdesc.extent: circa 1,800 items
22 boxes
14 linear feet

did.langmaterial: Collection material in English, and German
did.abstract: Holographs of original compositions, including sketches, transcriptions of other composers' music, manuscript and printed, correspondence, financial and legal documents, programs, clippings, photographs, and awards and honors. In addition, the collection contains papers of Kreisler biographer Louis Lochner, including personal papers of Kreisler and material related to the biography.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically therein.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: Gift of Fritz Kreisler, 1955; the Kreisler estate, 1970-1971; and Louis Lochner, 1960.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Fritz Kreisler Collection was processed in May 1992 by Claudia J. Widgery. This Finding Aid was prepared with Corel WordPerfect 8. In 2003, Michael A. Ferrando coded and edited the finding aid for EAD format.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: The status of copyright on the materials of the Fritz Kreisler Collection is governed by the Copyright Law of the United States (Title 17, U.S.C.).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: container number, Fritz Kreisler Collection, Music Division, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

chronitem.event: Born in Vienna to Samuel and Anna Kreisler
Studies at the Vienna Conservatory with Joseph Hellmesberger (violin) and Anton Bruckner (harmony and theory)
Wins gold medal of the Vienna Conservatory
Studies in Paris with Joseph Lambert Massart (violin) and Léo Delibes (composition)
Wins Premier Grand Prix of the Paris Conservatoire
U. S. debut with the Boston Symphony, Walter Damrosch conducting, while on a tour with pianist Moriz Rosenthal
Spends 2 years at Piaristen Gymnasium to pass his Abitur; takes 2 years of pre-medical training; spends 2 years as a soldier in the Kaiserjäger Regiment of Austrian army
Frequents the Tonkünstlerverein and Café Grünsteidl in Vienna with Brahms, Joachim, Wolf, Heuberer, and Hellmesberger
Performs in concerts in the United States and throughout Europe and Scandinavia
Marries Harriet Woerz (née Lies) in New York City
Copyrights Caprice viennois, Liebesfreud, Tambourin chinois, and Liebeslied
Performs world premiere of Elgar's Violin Concerto in B minor, which is dedicated to him
Serves one year as a lieutenant in the Austro-Hungarian army
Publishes Four weeks in the trenches with Macmillan & Company
Retires for the duration of World War I from paid performances due to American resentment of his service in the Austro-Hungarian army
Writes "Music and Life" for The Mentor
Performs throughout the world, including the Near and Far East, Scandinavia, Russia, Australia, and South America
Premiere of his operetta Sissy, the rose from Bavaria-land in Vienna

After Kreisler is questioned by Harold Spivacke about actual provenance of the Classical Manuscripts, the series is revealed by Olin Downes in the New York Times to be Kreisler's own original compositions rather than transcriptions
Awarded the French Legion of Honor; assumes French citizenship (officially granted in May 1939)
Charitable appearances to benefit organizations such as the American Red Cross, the Salvation Army, the Metropolitan Opera Association Fund, and the Musician's Emergency Fund
Skull fractured in traffic accident in New York City; successful return to concert stage at Carnegie Hall in October 1942
Radio debut on the Bell Telephone Company Hour with the NBC Symphony Orchestra conducted by Donald Voorhees
Final concert at Carnegie Hall
Public auction at Parke-Bernet Galleries of Kreisler's rare books, manuscripts, and artifacts earns over $120,000 for the Golden Rule Foundation and Lenox Hill Hospital
Dies in New York City

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Fritz Kreisler is known predominantly for his artistry as a violinist, particularly in performances of his own transcriptions and cadenzas, but he is also worthy of note as a composer. More than fifty of Kreisler's original compositions are represented in this collection, in sketch, manuscript, or printed form. Holographs of some of Kreisler's most popular compositions, such as Caprice viennois, Liebesfreud, and the Viennese rhapsodic fantasietta, are complemented by his manuscripts of less well-known works, including Drei Nachtgesänge (with poetry by Eichendorff) and his Song, op. 7, for violin and piano. Included among the holographs are several works of the Klassische Manuskripte series, a set of 14 pieces for violin and piano that were thought to be Kreisler's transcriptions of classical works until 1935, when it was revealed that they were his original compositions. Kreisler's Viennese light opera Sissy (1932) is also represented in the collection, both by holograph full scores of most of its individual numbers and by a complete printed vocal score.

Approximately 130 of Kreisler's transcriptions are included in the collection, adaptations of works by composers ranging from Corelli to Moussorgsky to Stephen Foster and Percy Grainger. The manuscripts and heavily annotated prints of Kreisler's transcriptions reveal the compositional process through which his characteristic virtuosic sound was achieved. For many such works there are 2 or more manuscript versions to compare with the holograph annotations to the printed edition.

The musical manuscripts and printed scores in the collection are by far its largest component, but they are supplemented by a number of Kreisler's personal papers, including correspondence, financial and legal documents, photographs, and honors. There are also various papers relating to Kreisler's violins and bows, and a collection of programs, itineraries, and clippings relevant to his activities as a performer.

The papers that journalist Louis Lochner (1887-1975) donated to the Library in 1960 are divided into two categories: those relating directly to Kreisler, and those pertaining to Lochner's 1950 biography, Fritz Kreisler. Kreisler's papers include letters, legal documents, and honors, as well as writings, programs, press releases, and clippings about Kreisler. Lochner's own papers Fritz Kreisler in the collection consist of notes and corrections for his biography, relevant correspondence, and other miscellaneous source material.

arrangement.head: Organization of the Fritz Kreisler Collection
arrangement.p: The Fritz Kreisler Collection is organized in 11 series:

list.item: Music
Writings
Correspondence
Performance Materials
Clippings
Photographs
Honors & Awards
Financial Papers
Legal Documents
Miscellaneous
Louis Lochner Papers

scopecontent.p: Fritz Kreisler is known predominantly for his artistry as a violinist, particularly in performances of his own transcriptions and cadenzas, but he is also worthy of note as a composer. More than fifty of Kreisler's original compositions are represented in this collection, in sketch, manuscript, or printed form. Holographs of some of Kreisler's most popular compositions, such as Caprice viennois, Liebesfreud, and the Viennese rhapsodic fantasietta, are complemented by his manuscripts of less well-known works, including Drei Nachtgesänge (with poetry by Eichendorff) and his Song, op. 7, for violin and piano. Included among the holographs are several works of the Klassische Manuskripte series, a set of 14 pieces for violin and piano that were thought to be Kreisler's transcriptions of classical works until 1935, when it was revealed that they were his original compositions. Kreisler's Viennese light opera Sissy (1932) is also represented in the collection, both by holograph full scores of most of its individual numbers and by a complete printed vocal score.

Approximately 130 of Kreisler's transcriptions are included in the collection, adaptations of works by composers ranging from Corelli to Moussorgsky to Stephen Foster and Percy Grainger. The manuscripts and heavily annotated prints of Kreisler's transcriptions reveal the compositional process through which his characteristic virtuosic sound was achieved. For many such works there are 2 or more manuscript versions to compare with the holograph annotations to the printed edition.

scopecontent.p: Writings, sketches and notes of Fritz Kreisler.

arrangement.p: Arrangement is by subject or title.

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series is arranged into three subseries: Letters received by Fritz Kreisler; Letters sent from Fritz Kreisler; and General Correspondence. The General Correspondence subseries is represented by letters received by and sent from the following: American Federation of Musicians; Thomas E. Dewey; Harriet Kreisler; Charles Foley; Louis Spohr; Sylvia Voorhees.

arrangement.p: The series is arranged into three subseries: Letters received by Fritz Kreisler; Letters sent from Fritz Kreisler; and General Correspondent. The arrangement is alphabetical by correspondent.

scopecontent.p: The papers that journalist Louis Lochner (1887-1975) donated to the Library in 1960 are divided into two categories: those relating directly to Kreisler, and those pertaining to Lochner's 1950 biography, Fritz Kreisler. Kreisler's papers include letters, legal documents, and honors, as well as writings, programs, press releases, and clippings about Kreisler. Lochner's own papers Fritz Kreislerin the collection consist of notes and corrections for his biography, relevant correspondence, and other miscellaneous source material.
